bibl.title: Despatch from Owen L. W. Smith to David J. Hill, December 20, 1900
Despatches from United States Consuls in Monrovia, 1852-1906

correspAction.roleName: U.S. Minister Resident and Consul General

div1.p: No. 57. Consular. Legation of the United States Monrovia Liberia Dec. 20, 1900
Hon. David J. Hill Assistant Secretary of State Washington.
Subject. Native Chiefs captured five (allied) native towns and five prisoner of war, Dec. 17, 1900.

Synopsis. Five (allied) Native towns captured, three burned, five prisoners of war, and notice served upon the National garison at Suehn that Suehn would be the next place of attack. The garrison asks for reinforcements.

Inasmuch as it has been very generally alleged that the Natives had nothing against the Government, as such; but against President Coleman, personally, that actuated their hostilities; and now that such fearful atrocities have been made , in one night times, since the resignation of President Coleman, the officials of the Government, including the Legislators, are very active endeavoring to conceal the facts of such occurances from the public and foreign representatives.
I have the honor to be your obedient servant; Owen L. W. Smith, M. R. and C. General.
